statement.p:
Consider the following true-life situation.
"I want to rent this room for the month of July," he said. The clerk wheezed. He peered through the narrow slits of his bloodshot eyes, glaring through the murk of the humid dusty darkness of the fleabag lobby, and said, "for youa deal." "How much?" said the big guy, sweat trickling down his face, staining the collar of his dingy shirt which didn't appear to have been washed in weeks. Noticing the telltale bulge of a revolver under the stranger's dirt-stained jacket, the clerk replied, "First dayone cent. Second daytwo cents. Third dayfour. Every day it doubles." The stranger's face drew into a knot as he scrutinized the greasy poker-faced clerk. He said, "That's nothin'. What's the hitch?"
How much would the stranger pay on July 31st?
What would the bill be for the month of July?

An investment portfolio has holdings in instruments X and Y. At a certain moment, both instruments have a value of 100 dollars. Beginning at that same moment, the value of X drops exactly 10 dollars every day, and the value of Y loses 20 percent of its value every day.
Assuming that the values of both investments are continuous functions of time, Which of X,Y is the first to reach a value of 20 dollars?
Explain how you know, without calculating, which investment is the first to reach a value of zero.

ol.li: Value functions are X(t) = 100 - 10t and Y(t)=100(.8)^t. Solve X(t)=20 and Y(t)=20 see that X(8)=20 and Y(7.21)\approx 20, so Y is the first to reach the value 20.
There is no t for which Y(t)=0 (the graph of Y is asymptotic to the t-axis). By contrast, the graph of X is linear, with a negative slope, so it must have a t intercept for some positive value of t.

statement.p: The Greek philosopher Zeno (ca. 450BC) considered the following motion problem. A rabbit and a turtle agree to run a race. Displaying good sportsmanship, the rabbit, who can run faster, gives the turtle a head start. Zeno argued that the rabbit will never catch the turtle, as follows. To catch the turtle, the rabbit must first travel from the starting point to the turtle's starting point. During this time, the turtle will advance. Let's call the turtle's new location point 2. Now the rabbit must travel to point 2, but during that time, the turtle advances to point 3. And so on. This process defines an infinite sequence of distinct points. Traveling from each one to the next requires a positive amount of time. Since an infinite sum of positive numbers must be infinite, Zeno concludes that the rabbit will never catch the turtle. Of course, Zeno knew there must be some flaw in this argument, but was unable to resolve the paradox satisfactorily.

Analyze Zeno's paradox under the following assumptions: the rabbit travels at a constant speed of 5 feet per second; the turtle travels at a constant speed of 2 feet per second; and the head start distance is 10 feet. Place coordinates on the race track with the rabbit beginning at 0 and the turtle beginning at 10, with both running in the positive direction.
Using high school algebra and the formula (\text{distance}) = (\text{rate})(\text{time}) find the location where the rabbit catches the turtle, and the time elapsed from the beginning of the race to the point where the rabbit catches the turtle.
Find the sequence of distances traveled by the rabbit from the rabbit's starting point to the turtle's starting point, from there to point 2, from point 2 to point 3, etc.
Find the sequence of times that elapse while the rabbit traveled the distance intervals in the previous part.
Use the theory of geometric sequences to resolve Zeno's paradox by reconciling your findings in the previous steps of this problem.

ol.li: Use R(t) for position of rabbit at time t, use T(t) for position of turtle at time t, so R(t) = 5t, T(t)=10+2t, solve R(t)=T(t) to get t=10/3 seconds; the rabbit at turtle meet at the point R(10/3)=T(10/3)=50/3 feet from the Rabbit's starting point
total time is \sum_{n=1}^\infty 2(2/5)^n = 2\left(\frac{1}{1-2/5}\right) = 10/3, total distance (for the rabbit) is \sum_{n=1}^\infty 10(2/5)^n = 10\left(\frac{1}{1-2/5}\right) = 50/3

statement.p: The following problem is a modern version of Zeno's paradox. It is taken from an article by George Andrews in the January 1998 issue of the American Mathematical Monthly, Vol. 105 No. 1 and is attributed to a Prof. Sleator.

Two trees are one mile apart. A drib flies from one tree to the other and back, making the first trip at 10 miles per hour, the return at 20 miles per hour, the next at 40 and so on, each successive mile at twice the speed of the preceding.
Write the first five terms of the sequence of velocities for trip numbers 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence.
Write the first five terms of the sequence times taken for trips 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence.
Write the first five terms of the sequence of how much time it takes the drib to travel 1 mile, 2 miles, 3 miles, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence.
Where is the drib 12 minutes after the first trip begins?

ol.li: Since the sequence in the previous part goes to 1/5 hour or 12 minutes, this means that in 12 minutes the drip has completed an infinite number of 1-mile trips. Perhaps the drib is in both trees at once?

Koch's snowflake is a geometric figure built recursively, as follows. Stage 1 is an equilateral triangle whose sides are 1 unit in length. To produce Stage n from Stage n-1, perform the replacement of edges illustrated in .

The snowflake is the figure obtained after infinitely many stages. Stages 1, 2, 3 and the finished snowflake are shown in .
The first three stages and the finished snowflake (https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:KochFlake.png)
Write the first 5 terms of the sequence of the number of edges in Stages 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence.
Write the first 5 terms of the sequence of the lengths of each edge in Stages 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence.
Write the first 5 terms of the sequence of the total perimeter of the figure for Stages 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence. Hint: Multiply your results from the previous two parts.
Write the first 5 terms of the sequence of the number of new equilateral triangle "bumps" added at Stages 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence. Hint: Adapt your result from part (a).
Write the first 5 terms of the sequence of areas of each new equilateral triangle "bump" added at Stages 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence. Hint: The area of an equilateral triangle whose side measures s units of length is s^2\sqrt{3}/4. Hint: Use part (b).
Write the first 5 terms of the sequence of the new area added (total area of all the new "bumps") at Stages 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence. Hint: Multiply your results from the previous two parts.
Write the first 5 terms of the sequence of total area for Stages 1, 2, 3, etc. Write an explicit formula for this sequence. Hint: Sum the terms of the geometric sequence from the previous part. Watch out! The first couple of terms may not fit the pattern of the sequence.
What is the perimeter of the snowflake?
What is the area of the snowflake?

ol.li: 3\cdot 4^{n-1}, n\geq 1
3\cdot 4^{n-2}, n\geq 2. Note that the first term in this sequence is 1.
\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{16}(\frac{4}{9})^{n-1}, n\geq 2. Note that the first term in this sequence is \sqrt{3}/4.
The perimeter is the limit as n\to\infty of the sequence in part c, which is infinity.
The area is the limit as n\to\infty of the sequence in part g, which is \frac{2\sqrt{3}}{5}.

subsection.title: Rational and Irrational Numbers
subsection.p:
A rational numberrational number is a number that can be written in the form a/b for some integers a,b. An irrational numberirrational number
is a real number that is not rational. The standard symbol for the set of rational numbersthe set of rational numbers
is \Q\Q the set of rational numbers . In set notation, we have \Q=\left\{\frac{a}{b}\colon a,b\in \Z, b\neq 0\right\}. The following is a classic proof by contradiction that proves that at least one irrational number exists.

statement.p: The number \sqrt{2} is irrational.

proof.p: Suppose on the contrary that \sqrt{2}=a/b is rational, where a,b are integers. We may assume both a,b are positive, and we may assume that the fraction a/b is reduced, that is, that a,b have no common factors other than 1. Squaring both sides of \sqrt{2}=a/b and rearranging, we have 2b^2=a^2. This says that a^2 is even, so it must be that a itself is even. That means we can write a=2k for some integer k. Substituting 2k for a in the equation 2b^2=a^2, we get 2b^2=(2k)^2=4k^2, which simplifies to b^2=2k^2. Now we see that b^2 is even, so it must be that b is even. But this means that a,b are both divisible by 2, which contradicts the assumption that a,b share no common factors. We conclude that \sqrt{2} is irrational.

statement.p: Justify the statement in the proof above that says "so a itself must be even". Give a proof that uses the results of . Give another proof that uses only the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: establishes that "an odd times an odd must be odd". Suppose now that 2|a^2. If a is odd, then a^2 is odd, but this contradicts that 2|a^2. Thus it must be that a is even.

For another proof, apply to conclude that if 2|a^2, then 2|a as well. Alternatively, apply the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic directly. Suppose a=p_1p_2\ldots p_r is a prime factorization of a. If 2|a^2, then one of the primes p_j must be 2, by uniqueness of prime factorization. Thus 2|a.

subsection.p: It turns out that irrational numbers are not rare or isolated among the real numbers; the rational numbers and irrational numbers are "everywhere" in the real line. The following proposition makes this statement precise. Recall that an open interval of the real line is a set of the form (a,b)=\{x\in \R\colon a\lt x\lt b\} for some real numbers a,b with a\lt b. We say that a subset X\subseteq \R is dense in \R if every open interval contains an element of X.

statement.p: The set \Q of rational numbers is dense in \R. The set \R\setminus \Q of irrational numbers is dense in \R.

proposition.proof: (This is an outline of the main points of the proof that \Q is dense in \R. In exercises below, you will complete the details of the proof of the density of the rationals, and you will also prove the density of the irrationals.) Let a,b be given, with a\lt b, and let \epsilon=b-a. Choose an integer n large enough so that 1/n \lt \epsilon. We claim that there is some integer multiple of 1/n that lies between a and b, that is, there is some integer m such that a\lt m/n \lt b. If not, then there exist consecutive integer multiples k/n,(k+1)/n of 1/n so that k/n \leq a \lt b\leq (k+1)/n. But then we would have b-a\leq (k+1)/n -k/n = 1/n, a contradiction. Thus we have shown that the open interval (a,b) contains a rational number. We conclude that \Q is dense in \R.

ol.li: In the proof outline of above, how do we know that we can "choose an integer n large enough"?
Explain why it is that "then we would have b-a\leq 1/n" (immediately after the displayed equation).
What does that contradict?
What allows us to "conclude that \Q is dense in \R"?

We start with the observation that, for any positive real number, there exists and integer that is larger. (This is called the Archimedean property of the real numbers, but we can be explicit by choosing n=\lceil 1/\epsilon \rceil + 1.) Thus, there exists some integer n such that n\gt 1/\epsilon. It follows that 1/n\lt \epsilon.
The situation is that we have 4 real numbers R,S,T,U with R\leq S\lt T\leq U. (Look at a sketch of these on the real number line.) It follows that T-S \leq U-V.
This contradicts our previous choice of n, which guarantees that 1/n\lt b-a.
Since the choice of a,b was arbitrary, this shows that every open interval of \R contains a rational number.

statement.p: Let n be a positive integer. Show that either n is a perfect square (that is, n=k^2 for some integer k), or \sqrt{n} is irrational.

exercise.hint: Let n be a positive integer, and suppose that \sqrt{n}=a/b is rational, where a,b are positive integers that share no common factors other than 1. Squaring and rearranging, we have nb^2=a^2. Let p be a prime factor of b. Explain why it must be that p|a. Explain why this implies that b=1. Explain how this implies the desired conclusion.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: (completing the outline given in the hint) By , if p|a^2, then p|a (you can also do this directly using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic). But p|a contradicts our assumption that a,b have no common factors other than 1. So there must not be any prime factors of b. This implies b=1. This means \sqrt{n}=a, so n=a^2 is a perfect square. We conclude that \sqrt{n} is either an integer or else \sqrt{n} must be irrational.

statement.p: Complete the proof of by showing that the irrationals are dense in the reals.

exercise.hint: Apply the density of \Q to the interval (a/\sqrt{2},b/\sqrt{2}).

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Let a,b be given, with a\lt b. Using the fact that the rationals are dense in the reals, there is some rational number, say m/n, that lies in the interval (a/\sqrt{2},b/\sqrt{2}), that is, we have a/\sqrt{2} \lt m/n \lt b/\sqrt{2}. Multiplying through by \sqrt{2}, we have a \lt m\sqrt{2}/n \lt b. We need only show that m\sqrt{2}/n is irrational. If not, then there are integers p,q such that m\sqrt{2}/n=p/q, so that \sqrt{2}=(pn)/(qm). But this is impossible, because \sqrt{2} is irrational. Thus we conclude that the interval (a,b) contains an irrational number, namely m\sqrt{2}/n. Since the choice of a,b was arbitrary, we conclude that the irrationals are dense in the reals.

Alternatively, you could follow the 4-step outline used to prove that the rationals are dense, making alterations to get to the point a\lt m\sqrt{2}/n\lt b for some integers m,n. Then you finish by showing m\sqrt{2}/n is irrational.

statement.p:
Choose an angle \theta_0. Starting at the point (1,0), walk around the unit circle in a counterclockwise direction, taking steps of size \theta_0. What is the smallest whole number of steps you have to take until you come for the first time to a point that you've already stepped on? Where is this first repeated location?
Find the answer for \theta_0 = 20 degrees.
Find the answer for \theta_0 = 27 degrees.
Find the answer for \theta_0 = \sqrt{2} degrees.
Find the answer for \theta_0 = 3\pi/2 radians.
Find the answer for \theta_0 = 1 radian. You may use the fact that \pi is irrational.
Find the answer for an arbitrary value of \theta_0. Suggestion: Rather than degrees or radians, you might consider using revolutions for your angle units.

ol.li: Because 20\cdot 18 = 360, the answer is 18 steps. The first revisited point is (1,0).

For a brute force solution, we can list the steps in order: 27,54,71,98,\ldots. We notice that 40 steps comes out to 3 trips around the circle (27\cdot 40 = 360\cdot 3) and that this is the first repeated position. So the answer is 40 steps, and the first revisited point is (1,0). [Comment: there are more insightful ways to solve this. You'll need a more general approach for part f below.]

Suppose there is some number of steps, say n, at which we visit a previously visited point. In those n steps, we would travel n\sqrt{2} degrees. To say that this is a previously visited point, it has to be true that we got to this point after some number, say m, steps, with m\lt n. This means that m\sqrt{2},n\sqrt{2} would have to be different by some whole number multiple of 360. So we would have n\sqrt{2}-m\sqrt{2}=360k for some integer k. Rearranging, we would have \sqrt{2}=\frac{360k}{n-m}. But this is impossible by the result of . We conclude that there will {\em never} be a repeated location when the step size is \sqrt{2} degrees.
4 steps, first revisited point is (1,0)
never repeats (similar argument as in part c)

li.p: Let \theta_0 be the step size, measured in revolutions. Suppose there is some step count n at which we revisit, for the first time, a previously visited point (the step count starts at 0 at the starting point (1,0)). To say that this is a previously visited point, it has to be true that we got to this point at some smaller step count m\lt n. We claim that m must be zero. Indeed, if n' is the step count on which we revisit a previously visited point, which we previously visited at m'\lt n' steps, then we would also have revisited the start point (1,0) at the step count n'-m'. By assumption, n is the smallest step count at which we revisit any point, so we must have m=0.

In n steps, we travel n\theta_0 = k revolutions, where k \geq 1 is some integer. Solving this last equation, we get \theta=\frac{k}{n}. Notice that, because n,k are the smallest possible integers in the fraction that represents \theta_0, it must be that the fraction k/n is reduced. Furthermore, if \theta_0 is not rational, it must be that there is no point on the circle that is ever revisited in any number of steps.

To summarize: steps of rational size \theta_0=a/b revolutions, with a,b reduced, will first repeat after b steps, and the first repeat location is (1,0). This occurs after traveling exactly a times around the circle. Steps of an irrational number of revolutions will never repeat.

statement.p: Your intelligent younger cousin declares to you that 1.\overline{9}=1.999\ldots \text{(infinitely repeating 9's)} is less than 2. How do you explain that 1.\overline{9} is actually equal to 2?

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Let x=1.\overline{9}. Then 10x= 19.\overline{9}, and 9x=10x-x=19.\overline{9}=1.\overline{9}=18, so we must have x=2. Another way to see why 1.\overline{9}=2 is to use the sum formula for geometric series. We have .\overline{9} = .9 + .09 + .009 + \cdots = \sum_{n=0}^\infty .9(.1)^n. This is a geometric series with initial term .9 and common ratio .1, and so it sums to the value \displaystyle .9\left(\frac{1}{1-.1}\right) = 1. Therefore we have x=1.\overline{9}=1+.\overline{9} = 2.

statement.p: Show that a number is rational if and only if it has a decimal representation that eventually repeats or terminates.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p:
Suppose that x has a repeating decimal representation x = X_kX_{k-1}\ldots X_2X_1.\overline{d_1d_2\ldots d_r} where the symbols X_j and d_\ell represent digits 0\ldots 9. Then we have the following. 10^r \amp = X_kX_{k-1}\ldots X_2X_1d_1d_2\ldots d_r.\overline{d_1d_2\ldots d_r}\\ (10^r-1)x \amp = 10^rx-x =X_kX_{k-1}\ldots X_2X_1d_1d_2\ldots d_r - X_kX_{k-1}\ldots X_2X_1
which is a whole number, say N. Thus we have x = N/(10^r-1), so we see that x is a rational number. If the decimal for x terminates, then we simply have x=\frac{N}{10^r} for the integer N=10^rx, where r is the length of the finite block of digits to the right of the decimal point.

Conversely, suppose that x=a/b is a rational number, where a,b are whole numbers with b\neq 0. For the case when a,b are both positive, long division produces a decimal representation for x through repeated use of the division algorithm, where each stage produces a remainder r in the range 0\leq r\lt b-1. If at any stage we obtain a remainder r=0, the decimal terminates. If we never obtain a remainder r=0, then eventually we must obtain a remainder that we have had before. At this point, the division process begins a repeating block that repeats forever. If x is negative, we apply the same argument to |x| to obtain a terminating or repeating decimal, then x is represented by this decimal with a minus sign in front of it.

statement.p:
Prove the following facts about terminating decimal expansions.
Suppose that m=2^s5^t for some nonnegative integers s,t. Show that the rational number n/m (n also an integer) has a terminating decimal expansion.
Suppose that the reduced rational number n/m (n,m integers with no common factors, m\neq 0) has a terminating decimal expansion. Show that m=2^s5^t for some nonnegative integers s,t.

Given a set A, the power setpower set of A, denoted {\mathcal P}(A){\mathcal P}(A) power set of a set A
, is defined to be the set of all subsets of A. For example, for A=\{a,b,c\}, we have {\mathcal P}(A) = \{\emptyset,\{a\},\{b\},\{c\},\{a,b\},\{a,c\},\{b,c\},\{a,b,c\}\}.
Why is the empty set considered a subset of A?
Write out all of the possible functions from A to \{0,1\}. Hint: there are 8 in all.
Can you see a natural one-to-one correspondence between the power set of A and the list of functions you just wrote down?

ol.li: Given any two sets X,Y, it must be that case that either X\subseteq Y or X\not\subseteq Y. The set X is not a subset of set Y if X contains some element that is not also an element of Y. Because the empty set does not contain any element that is not an element of A, it must be that the empty set is a subset of A.

We will write a 3-bit string ijk to denote the function A\to \{0,1\} given by f(a)=i, f(b)=j, f(c)=k. For example, the string 010 denotes the function given by a\mapsto 0, b\mapsto 1, c\mapsto 0. Using this notation, the 8 functions A\to \{0,1\} are the following. 000, 001, 010, 011, 100, 101, 110, 111

Given a function f\colon A\to \{0,1\}, define the set S_{f} by S_{f} = \{x\in A\colon f(x)=1\}. Using this correspondence, the list of bit strings in the previous part correspond to the following subsets of A \emptyset, \{c\}, \{b\},\{b,c\}, \{a\}, \{a,c\}, \{a,b\}, \{a,b,c\}
A power set of a set S satisfies i, ii, iii, and iv because it contains every subset of S.
Here is a minimal example: Let S=\{a\} and consider \mathcal{A}=\{\emptyset\}. This satisfies i, ii, and iii, but not iv.

statement.p:
Let S be a set. Given a subset A of S, the characteristic functioncharacteristic function for a set
for A (relative to S), denoted \chi_A\colon S\to \{0,1\}\chi_A characteristic function for the set A
, is given by \chi_A(x) =\left\{ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp \mbox{if } x\in A\\ 0 \amp \mbox{if } x\not\in A\\ \end{array}\right.. Let A,B be subsets of S. Prove the following. The symbol "\oplus" denotes addition modulo 2.
A=B if and only if \chi_A=\chi_B
(\chi_A)^2 = \chi_A
\chi_{A\cap B} = \chi_A\cdot \chi_B
\chi_{A\cup B} = \chi_A \oplus \chi_B \oplus (\chi_A\cdot \chi_B)
\chi_{S\setminus A} = 1\oplus \chi_A
\chi_{S\setminus (A\cup B)} = (1 \oplus \chi_A)(1 \oplus \chi_B)

ol.li: Suppose A=B, and let x be an element in S. If x\in A, we have \chi_A(x)=1=\chi_B(x). If x\not\in A, then we have \chi_A(x)=0=\chi_B(x). Thus, for all x\in S, we have \chi_A(x)=\chi_B(x). In other words, the functions \chi_A,\chi_B are equal. Conversely, suppose that \chi_A=\chi_B. If x\in A, we have \chi_A(x)=1, so \chi_B(x)=1, which means that x\in B. This shows that every element in A is also in B, so we have A\subseteq B. Likewise, if x\in B, then \chi_B(x)=1, so \chi_A(x)=1, which means that x\in A. This shows that B\subseteq A. Having proved that A\subseteq B and B\subseteq A, we conclude that A=B.

If x\in A, then \chi_A(x)=1, so (\chi_A(x))^2=1. If x\not\in A, then \chi_A(x)=0, so (\chi_A(x))^2=0. Thus, for all possible values of x, we have (\chi_A(x))^2=\chi_A(x). This means that the functions \chi_A,(\chi_A)^2 are equal.

If x is in A\cap B, then \chi_{A\cap B}(x)=1, and \chi_A(x)\chi_B(x)=1\cdot 1 = 1. If x is not an element of A, or if x is not an element of B, or both, then x is not in A\cap B, so \chi_{A\cap B}(x)=0, and at least one of \chi_A(x),\chi_B(x) is zero, so \chi_A(x)\chi_B(x)=0. Thus, for all possible values of x, we have \chi_{A\cap B}(x)=\chi_A(x)\chi_B(x). This means that the functions \chi_{A\cap B}, \chi_A\chi_B are equal.

li.p: We consider four possibilities for x\in S.

ol.li: x\in A and x\in B
x\in A and x\not\in B
x\not\in A and x\in B
x\not\in A and x\not\in B

li.p: For possibility i, we have \chi_{A\cup B}(x)=1, and \chi_A(x) \oplus \chi_B(x) \oplus \chi_{A\cap B}(x) = 1\oplus 1\oplus 1\cdot 1 = 1. For possibility ii, we have \chi_{A\cup B}(x)=1, and \chi_A(x) \oplus \chi_B(x) \oplus \chi_{A\cap B}(x) = 1\oplus 0\oplus 1\cdot 0 = 1. For possibility iii, we have \chi_{A\cup B}(x)=1, and \chi_A(x) \oplus \chi_B(x) \oplus \chi_{A\cap B}(x) = 0\oplus 1\oplus 0\cdot 1 = 1. For possibility iv, we have \chi_{A\cup B}(x)=0, and \chi_A(x) \oplus \chi_B(x) \oplus \chi_{A\cap B}(x) = 0\oplus 0\oplus 0\cdot 0 = 0. In all four cases, we have \chi_{A\cup B}(x) =\chi_A(x) \oplus \chi_B(x) \oplus \chi_{A\cap B}(x), so we conclude the equality of functions \chi_{A\cup B} =\chi_A \oplus \chi_B \oplus \chi_{A\cap B}.

statement.p:
Let A,B,C be sets. Prove the following (the first two are distributive lawsdistributive laws for sets
for sets and the second two are De Morgan's lawsDe Morgan's laws). Hint: use characteristic functions from above.
A\cap(B\cup C)=(A\cap B)\cup (A\cap C)
A\cup(B\cap C)=(A\cup B)\cap (A\cup C)
S\setminus{(A\cap B)} = (S\setminus A) \cup (S\setminus B)
S\setminus{(A\cup B)} = (S\setminus A) \cap (S\setminus B)

ol.li: (similar to part a)

Again we will use equality of characteristic functions to establish equality of sets. Beginning with the set on the right side, we have
\chi_{(S\setminus A) \cup (S\setminus B)} \amp = \chi_{(S\setminus A)} \oplus \chi_{(S\setminus B)}\oplus \chi_{(S\setminus A)} \chi_{(S\setminus B)} \amp \amp \text{(part d above)} \amp = (1\oplus \chi_A)\oplus (1\oplus \chi_B) \oplus (1\oplus \chi_A)(1\oplus \chi_B)\amp \amp \text{(part e above)} \amp = 1\oplus \chi_A \oplus 1\oplus \chi_B \oplus 1\oplus \chi_A\oplus \chi_B \oplus \chi_A\chi_B\amp \amp \text{(distributing)} \amp = 1\oplus \chi_A\chi_B \amp \amp \text{(simplifying multiples of 2 to zero)} \amp = 1\oplus \chi_{(A\cap B)}\amp \amp \text{(part c above)} \amp = \chi_{S\setminus(A\cap B)}\amp \amp \text{(part e above)}.
The last expression is the characteristic function for the set on the left.
(similar to part c)

statement.p:
A partitionpartition of a set S is a collection of nonempty subsets of S whose union is all of S and any two of which have empty intersection.
Let S=\{a,b,c\}. Write out all possible partitions of S.
Give an example of a collection of subsets of S=\{a,b,c\} whose union is all of S, but some two of which have nonempty intersection.
Give an example of a collection of subsets of S=\{a,b,c\}, any two of which have empty intersection, but whose union is not all of S.

subsection.title: Pythagorean Triples
subsection.p:
A 3-tuple (a,b,c) of positive integers is called a Pythagorean triplePythagorean triple
if there exists a right triangle with leg lengths a,b and hypotenuse length c. A Pythagorean triple is primitiveprimitive Pythagorean triple if a,b,c have no common divisor (other than 1).

A point (p,q) on the unit circle is called a rational point if both p,q are rational numbers. Let Q be the open first quadrant of the unit circle in the x,y-plane (that is, points on the unit circle with both coordinates positive). The following exercises explore the details of the one-to-one correspondences
\{\text{primitive Pythagorean triples}\} \longleftrightarrow \{\text{rational points on } Q\} \longleftrightarrow \{\text{rational numbers } a\gt 1\}.

statement.p: Given a Pythagorean triple (a,b,c) (not necessarily primitive), show that (a/c,b/c) is a rational point on Q (see ).
Let (a,b,c) be a primitive Pythagorean triple. Show that a,c share no common divisors other than 1.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Suppose that a,c share some common divisor, say k, and let p be a prime factor of k. Then b^2=c^2-a^2 also has a prime factor p, so (a,b,c) would not be primitive.

statement.p: Let (p,q) be a point in Q with both p,q rational. Show that there is a unique reduced Pythagorean triple that maps to (p,q) via (a,b,c)\to (a/c,b/c). Use this to explain why there is a one-to-one correspondence \{\text{primitive Pythagorean triples}\} \longleftrightarrow \{\mbox{rational points on } Q\}.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Let (p,q) be a point in Q with both p,q rational. First, write p=\frac{s}{t},q=\frac{u}{v} for some integers s,t,u,v. Multiplying both sides of \left(\frac{s}{t}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{u}{v}\right)^2=1 by (tv)^2, we get (sv)^2+(tu)^2=(tv)^2. Note that (sv,tu,tv) is a Pythagorean triple, and that (sv/tv,tu/tv)=(p,q). If (sv,tu,tv) is not primitive, then we can remove all common factors and produce a primitive triple (a,b,c) such that (a/c,b/c)=(p,q).

Now suppose that there is another reduced Pythagorean triple (d,e,f) such that (d/f,e/f)=(p,q). Then we have a/c=d/f. Rearranging, we have af=dc. Because a,c share no common factors (by above), it must be that all the prime factors of a are also prime factors of d, so we have a|d. Likewise, we have c|f. But the same argument applies to show that d|a and f|c, so we have a=d and c=f, and it follows that (a,b,c)=(d,e,f).

The above arguments show that the function f\colon \{\text{primitive Pythagorean triples}\}\to \{\text{rational points on } Q\} given by f(a,b,c)=(a/c,b/c) is surjective (we showed that for every rational point (p,q) on Q, there is at least one primitive Pythagorean triple (a,b,c) such that f(a,b,c)=(p,q)) and also injective (we showed there is at most one reduced Pythagorean triple in the preimage of (p,q)). We conclude that f is a one-to-one correspondence.

statement.p: Find a formula for s^{-1}\colon (1,\infty)\to Q. Verify that your formula really gives an inverse for s by showing that s^{-1}\of s=\One_{Q} and s\of s^{-1}=\One_{(1,\infty)}.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: To find a formula for s^{-1}, we solve the pair of equations x/(1-y)=a and x^2+y^2=1 for x and y in terms of a. We obtain s^{-1}(a) = \left(\frac{2a}{a^2+1},\frac{a^2-1}{a^2+1}\right). Now check (do the algebra!) that s^{-1}(s(x,y))=(x,y) and s(s^{-1}(a))=a.

statement.p: Use the formulas for s,s^{-1} to explain why there is a one-to-one correspondence \{\mbox{rational points on } Q\} \longleftrightarrow \{\text{rational numbers } a\gt 1\}.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: Observe that rational points go to rational numbers under s, and rational numbers go to rational points under s^{-1}.
